Recently the California Department of Education
and California Department of Public Health released updated guidance on safely opening schools for the 2020-2021 school year. HBCSD will review guidance documents and use them along with input from stakeholders to plan for the 2020-2021 school year. The input from you, our HBCSD families, is an essential part of our planning process to safely open our schools. We will be sending out a parent survey directly to parent email addresses on Wednesday, June 17. The email will come from Qualtrics, a vendor that Orange County Department of Education uses. Please check your spam folder if you do not see the email. The plans to safely reopen schools will continue to be developed and evolve throughout the summer as more information becomes available. Follow up information with more specific details regarding our 2020-2021 plans will be sent to families at a later date. We appreciate your input and hope you continue to be well through these uncertain times. Orange County Department of Education

post_text: Anoche, la Junta Directiva de HBCSD votó (5-0) para cerrar permanentemente la Escuela Primaria Perry al final del año escolar 2019-2020. Este cierre no está relacionado con COVID-19, pero aborda la disminución de la matrícula estudiantil y apoya el plan de estabilidad fiscal adoptado por el distrito. Como resultado de esta decisión, el personal de HBCSD tiene la tarea de volver a dibujar las líneas fronterizas de los estudiantes con un enfoque en impactar al menor número de estudiantes. Se proporcionará más información a nuestra comunidad escolar a medida que nos embarquemos en este difícil proceso de cerrar una escuela mientras nos preparamos para el año escolar 2020-2021. Orange County Department of Education

post_text: Last night, the HBCSD Board of Trustees voted (5-0) to permanently close Perry Elementary School at the conclusion of the 2019-2020 school year. This closure is not related to COVID-19 but addresses declining student enrollment and supports the district’s adopted fiscal stability plan. As a result of this decision, HBCSD staff are tasked with redrawing student boundary lines with a focus on impacting the least number of students. More information will be provided to our school community as we embark on this difficult process of closing a school while also preparing for the 2020-2021 school year. www.hbcsd.k12.ca.us Orange County Department of Education

shared_text:
World Health Organization (WHO)
April 9 at 5:49 AM ·

Kids, meet Ario - a kind, orange dragon with a horn like a unicorn, who will introduce you to COVID-19 and help you understand how to protect yourself, your families and friends from the coronavirus.

A new story book “My Hero is You, How kids can fight COVID-19!” - aimed at children aged 6-11 years old, is released today to help children understand and come to terms with COVID-19.
The story book also explains to children how to manage difficult emotions when confronted with a new and rapidly changing reality.

This book has been produced by a collaboration of more than 50 organizations working in the humanitarian sector, incl. WHO, UNICEF, UNHCR, the UN Refugee Agency, International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies and Save the Children US.

We are grateful to Howard Donald for giving the first public reading of this book “My Hero is You - how kids can fight COVID-19" in support of the "Read The World" initiative by the International Publishers Association, UNICEF & WHO.

Watch the reading on our YouTube - link in comment below!

The idea is that minimizing social contact can effectively slow the spread of a virus so you don’t get a huge wave of illnesses all at once. If that were to happen, a community might not have enough hospital beds or staff to manage patient care.

As explained in this brief video produced by OCDE’s Media Services, infectious disease experts say it helps to spread cases out over weeks or months so that health care systems can keep pace.

Parent Education Night: "Recognizing the Dangers of Vaping in Our Youth"

Please join HBCSD and Orange County Department of Education on Wednesday, January 22 @ 6pm as we share information regarding the dangers of vaping in our youth. You will learn how to recognize vape and e-cigarette devices, the dangers of nicotine vaping, current vaping trends among our youth, and helpful tools and tips for parents. This evening is designed for parents of upper elementary and middle school students. Children/students should not be in attendance. Please RSVP using the link (https://tinyurl.com/r79vx4x) so we may have enough materials for all attendees. We look forward to a very informative evening!
